addy.message: Be humble, communicate clearly, and respect others. It costs nothing to be kind, but the impact is priceless.

I got to meet James Franco at Google today. 

He's super down to earth. We talked about his latest movie The Disaster Artist and The Room (the best, worst movie ever made) whose story it is based on. 

James noted there were many parallels between his life and Tommy Wiseau, the main character in the movie. In particular, their struggles having a creative vision and trying to see it through to fruition when many people in hollywood just say no.

James also shared that he no longer googles himself..but used to all the time :)

Some things you might find interesting:

James occasionally writes book reviews and wrote one back in 2013 about the Disaster Artist (well before he secured the rights to the story). I enjoyed reading it: https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/dpwvgw/universalizing-art-the-disaster-artist-and-the-room. 

The protagonist (Tommy Wiseau) still remains a total mystery to most people. No one knows where he got his money to finance ($6M) his movie "The Room" from (he told James it was from selling Levis Jeans on the street), no one knows where Tommy is really from or his age. 

He describes Tommy as someone that can look like a Pirate Vampire. If you've never come across Tommy Wiseau, check out the interview James and Tommy did on Jimmy Fallon from last night and you might get a sense for why :) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aT1gOazMMm8 He's still pretty cool and fascinating as a character.

I'm hoping to check out the Disaster Artist at a movie theatre soon. If you've checked it out or are going to, let me know what you think!

"Learning JavaScript Design Patterns" turns 5 today 🎂

My little book has been available to freely read online for 5 years. In that time it's been read by 1.6 million developers across 3.7 million sessions*. 

I can't thank the community enough for recommending the book to their friends and colleagues ❤️ I never imagined that I'd one day hear that it helped fellow Googlers and JavaScripters first learn about design patterns in a way that made sense to them. That said, I know the book could be far better.

JavaScript has evolved so much since this was first written. When there's time, I would love to do a rewrite that includes ES2015+, talks about ES Modules, classes, Babel transforms and where we need to rethink some of these patterns. 

Until I have time to work on that, thank you for making the book a success. I hope that it's been useful!

Book online: https://bit.ly/jsdesignpatterns
On Amazon: https://amzn.com/1449331815
Analytics: https://bit.ly/jsdpstat

Some trivia if you've made it this far down in the post :)

I wrote the very first version of this book in 7 days. It started off as a silly attempt to try figuring out how I could apply what I had learned from the 'Gang of Four' design patterns book to JavaScript. The book took a long time to refine after that. I most heavily used the Module and Mediator patterns in the larger ES5 apps I wrote back in the day.

My biggest "geek out" moment was when Stoyan Stefanov, who heavily influenced my JavaScript career, shared a Facebook post calling his JavaScript patterns book and mine sisters!

Getting to read I've helped someone makes my day. Thanks for those that left kind feedback.

I get a lot of emails asking what the best place to start learning React, ES6 or Node might be. The courses I've been recommending are the three below from Wes Bos.

💻 Learn Node & Express: https://bit.ly/learn-nodejs
⚛️ Learn React: https://bit.ly/learn-reactjs
䷢ Learn ES6: https://bit.ly/learn-es6

There are definitely free courses out there. What I've liked about this set is that they're super practical, help you build a real app by the end of them and they get _updated_. Check them out if you'd benefit from a brush up on some skills.

If you can't afford the courses, there's also https://github.com/enaqx/awesome-react and https://github.com/sindresorhus/awesome-nodejs that have a ton of resources on there too that are decent and also totally free.

Twitter.com is now a Progressive Web App on mobile 🎉

This month, Twitter shipped a new React rewrite of twitter.com as a PWA. If you go visit the site on your Android phone, you'll get a fast, slick experience that can be added to your homescreen 📱

I was honored to be able to help get this awesome work out the door (along with other colleagues on the Chrome team). The app uses Webpack, code-splitting ✂️, link rel=preload. Service Worker for caching static resources. Lots of smart loading techniques.

It's also the first large-scale U.S site to ship support for the PRPL pattern (article on it is at https://bit.ly/prpl-pattern). Hoping to get out a case study on the awesome work Nicolas Gallagher and the Twitter eng team did here in the coming months.

If you're interested in learning more about React, Webpack and PWAs, see my free 4-part series: https://addyosmani.com/blog/progressive-web-apps-with-react/

Progressive Web Apps across React, Angular and Ember - my Google I/O 2016 talk from today is now on YouTube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=srdKq0DckXQ 📹

It's been a challenging (but fun) six weeks looking at how to build apps using frameworks and pushing them for an instant loading experience. It's fascinating to see how far we've come with Universal/Isomorphic rendering, how low-friction Service Worker can be added to existing apps and where we still have work that can be done to improve the performance and developer experience around things like Indexed DB. 

I'm looking forward to working more closely with framework authors over the next few months to see what we can do to bake in better defaults for Progressive Web Apps and performance patterns like Application Shell into framework tooling so you have to do less work to get them setup. In the mean time, I hope the talk wasn't too terrible :) I'm looking forward to getting some sleep!

Remixing music in a web browser. Turn on sound to listen 🔊 

https://instagram.com/p/8yDGt2jF6V/
WIP demo: https://decks.firebaseapp.com/ (will require your own files)

This uses Tone.js (Web Audio framework - https://github.com/Tonejs/Tone.js) for helpers and NexusUI (http://nexusosc.com/) for audio controls which work pretty well on touch interfaces - mostly powered by the canvas element. Heavily inspired by work from Lee Tusman, Tim Bieniosek, Jason Sigal & Tommy Payne.

Currently works well with scratching, crossfade, track mixing and speed control.

Elevator.js makes scrolling back to the top of a page so much more fun!: https://instagram.com/p/8bm6b5jF5n
